title: Getting Started with Git
description: Learn the basics of Git version control system

steps.heading: Installing Git
steps.explanation: First, you need to install Git on your system. Visit the official Git website or use your package manager.
steps.code:
# On macOS with Homebrew
brew install git

# On Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install git

# On Windows, download from git-scm.com

steps.heading: Configure Git
steps.explanation: Set up your identity so your commits are properly attributed to you.
steps.code:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

steps.heading: Initialize a Repository
steps.explanation: Create a new Git repository in your project directory.
steps.code:
cd your-project
git init

title: Git Branching
description: Master the art of branching and merging in Git

steps.heading: Create a New Branch
steps.explanation: Branches allow you to work on different features independently.
steps.code:
git branch feature-name
# or create and switch in one command
git checkout -b feature-name

steps.heading: Switch Between Branches
steps.explanation: Move between different branches to work on various features.
steps.code:
git checkout main
git checkout feature-name
# or using the newer switch command
git switch main

steps.heading: Merge Branches
steps.explanation: Combine changes from one branch into another.
steps.code:
# First, switch to the target branch
git checkout main
# Then merge the feature branch
git merge feature-name

title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
description: Host your static website for free using GitHub Pages

steps.heading: Create a Repository
steps.explanation: Create a new repository on GitHub for your website.
steps.code:
# Create repo on GitHub, then clone it
git clone https://github.com/username/repo-name.git
cd repo-name

steps.heading: Add Your Files
steps.explanation: Add your HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files to the repository.
steps.code:
# Add all files
git add .
# Commit the changes
git commit -m "Initial commit"
# Push to GitHub
git push origin main

steps.heading: Enable GitHub Pages
steps.explanation: Go to your repository settings, navigate to 'Pages' section, and select your branch as the source. Your site will be live at username.github.io/repo-name.
steps.code:
# No code needed - this is done in GitHub UI
# Settings > Pages > Source > Deploy from branch
# Select 'main' branch and '/ (root)' folder

title: SSH + GitHub SSH Setup (ed25519 + Port 443)
description: Complete guide to SSH into a server, generate ed25519 keys, configure GitHub SSH with Port 443, and set up Git

steps.heading: Connect to the Server
steps.explanation: Open Terminal and SSH into your school server. When prompted, type 'yes' if asked to continue connecting, then enter your password.

steps.heading: Switch to Bash (Optional)
steps.explanation: Switch to bash shell for better compatibility. This step is optional but recommended.
steps.code: bash

steps.heading: Create .ssh Folder
steps.explanation: Create the .ssh directory if it doesn't exist and navigate into it. You can verify your location with pwd.
steps.code:
mkdir -p ~/.ssh
cd ~/.ssh

# Optional: verify directory
pwd

steps.heading: Generate SSH Key (ed25519)
steps.explanation: Generate a new SSH key using the ed25519 algorithm. Press Enter for default file location, and Enter again for no passphrase (or set one if you prefer).
steps.code: ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

steps.heading: Show and Copy Public Key
steps.explanation: Display your public key and copy the entire output (starts with 'ssh-ed25519'). You'll need this for GitHub.
steps.code: cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

steps.heading: Add Public Key to GitHub
steps.explanation: On GitHub: Go to Settings > SSH and GPG keys > New SSH key. Give it a title like 'School Server Key', paste your public key, and click 'Add SSH key'.
steps.code:
# No terminal command needed
# 1. Go to GitHub Settings
# 2. Click 'SSH and GPG keys'
# 3. Click 'New SSH key'
# 4. Title: School Server Key
# 5. Paste your public key
# 6. Click 'Add SSH key'

steps.heading: Configure SSH for Port 443
steps.explanation: Create/edit the SSH config file to force GitHub SSH connections through Port 443. This bypasses firewall restrictions. Use Ctrl+O then Enter to save, and Ctrl+X to exit nano.
steps.code:
nano ~/.ssh/config

# Paste this content:
Host github.com
  HostName ssh.github.com
  User git
  Port 443
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

steps.heading: Fix SSH Permissions
steps.explanation: Set the correct permissions for your SSH files. This is important for security and proper SSH operation.
steps.code:
chmod 700 ~/.ssh
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/config
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

steps.heading: Set Git Global Config
steps.explanation: Configure Git with your name and email so your commits are properly attributed. Optionally set 'main' as your default branch.
steps.code:
git config --global user.name "Your Full Name"
git config --global user.email "your_email@example.com"

# Optional: set default branch to main
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

# Optional: verify your config
git config --global --list

steps.heading: Verify GitHub SSH Connection
steps.explanation: Test your SSH connection to GitHub. If successful, you'll see a message like 'Hi USERNAME! You've successfully authenticated...' Type 'yes' if asked to trust the host.
steps.code: ssh -T git@github.com

steps.heading: Return Home and Exit
steps.explanation: Navigate back to your home directory and exit the server when you're done. Remember: never share your private key (id_ed25519), only share the public key (id_ed25519.pub).
steps.code:
cd ~
pwd  # Optional: confirm location

# When done, exit the server
exit

title: App1 – Minimal Python Web App (WSGI + Jinja2 + Gunicorn)
description: Build a plain Python WSGI app using Jinja2 and Gunicorn inside a virtual environment

steps.heading: Go to Home Directory
steps.explanation: Start by navigating to your home directory.
steps.code: cd ~

steps.heading: Copy the Virtual Environment
steps.explanation: Copy the preconfigured Python virtual environment to your home directory. This must be done first before activating.
steps.code: cp -r /opt/virt ~/

steps.heading: Activate the Virtual Environment
steps.explanation: Activate the virtual environment. You should see (virt) at the start of your prompt when activated.
steps.code:
source ~/virt/bin/activate

# You should see:
# (virt) username@server:~$

steps.heading: Create webapps Directory
steps.explanation: Create and navigate into the webapps directory where your applications will live.
steps.code:
mkdir webapps
cd webapps

steps.heading: Create app1 Directory
steps.explanation: Create and navigate into the app1 directory for this specific application.
steps.code:
mkdir app1
cd app1

steps.heading: Create Empty GitHub Repository and Clone It
steps.explanation: Create an empty repository on GitHub, then clone it. The 'empty repository' warning is expected and fine.
steps.code:
git clone git@github.com:xalhexi-sch/App1.git

# You may see:
# warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.
# This is expected and fine.

steps.heading: Create app.py
steps.explanation: Create the main application file using nano. This is a pure WSGI app using Jinja2 for templating. Save with Ctrl+O then Enter, exit with Ctrl+X.
steps.code:
nano app.py

# Paste this code:
from jinja2 import Environment, FileSystemLoader
import os

BASE_DIR = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))

env = Environment(
    loader=FileSystemLoader(os.path.join(BASE_DIR, "templates")),
    autoescape=True
)

def app(environ, start_response):
    path = environ.get("PATH_INFO", "/")

    if path.endswith("/hello"):
        title = "Hello Page"
        message = "Rendered using Jinja2"
    else:
        title = "Home"
        message = "Plain Python + Gunicorn + Nginx"

    template = env.get_template("home.html")
    html = template.render(title=title, message=message)

    start_response("200 OK", [("Content-Type", "text/html; charset=utf-8")])
    return [html.encode("utf-8")]

steps.heading: Create Templates Folder and HTML File
steps.explanation: Create the templates directory and the home.html template file. This uses Jinja2 syntax with {{ variable }} placeholders.
steps.code:
mkdir templates cd templates nano home.html # Paste this HTML: {{ title }}

{{ title }}

{{ message }}

steps.heading: Return to App Root
steps.explanation: Navigate back to the app1 directory and verify your location with pwd.
steps.code:
cd ..
pwd

# Expected output:
# ~/webapps/app1

steps.heading: Run the App Using Gunicorn
steps.explanation: Start the application using Gunicorn. You can change the port (5000) if needed. The app:app refers to the app function inside app.py.
steps.code: gunicorn --bind 127.0.0.1:5000 app:app

steps.heading: Access the App
steps.explanation: Access your app through the server URL. The exact URL depends on your server/proxy setup.
steps.code:
# Example URL (depends on your server setup):
# http://172.17.100.15:9899/it21_banas/webapps/app1

# Final folder structure:
# webapps/
# └── app1/
#     ├── app.py
#     └── templates/
#         └── home.html
